awd_titl_txt: Doctoral dissertation research: The dynamics of visual media and social change
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

How individuals adjust identity to social change is an important question, as such adjustments affect how individuals understand their place within larger social and political structures. Social change offers opportunities to clarify fundamental tensions in modern societies between individualism versus collectivism and between private versus communal property. This doctoral dissertation research investigates whether and how visual media reflect and/or drive social change in rapidly changing socio-economic landscapes. The work provides a unique lens for investigating these dynamic feedbacks in ways that illustrate whether, how, and at what pace expressions of identity change in relation to larger socio-economic structures. The research contributes to training a U.S. doctoral student and its findings will be distributed widely to diverse audiences. 

Specifically, the project investigates what the economic and aesthetic strategies of contemporary visual media reveal about the socio-economic role of creative work in societies undergoing fundamental social and economic transformations. It considers whether and how concepts of property are exposed and reworked in the self-presentation, material production, and exhibition infrastructures of visual media during periods of rapid social change. Using an integration of ethnographic and archival methods, the doctoral student examines regional visual media as they respond to recent domestic socio-economic reforms in a context where transitions between collectivist and individualist notions of belonging are shifting. The student integrates direct observation, analysis of printed material, as well as interviews with relevant stakeholders to understand how regional visual media have responded to changes in property legislation following privatizing reforms. The results of this research provide a more robust account of visual media as both a barometer of and participant in processes of social, political-economic, and cultural change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
How individuals adjust identity to social, political, and economic change is an important question, as such adjustments affect how individuals understand their place within larger social and political structures. Dramatic social change offers opportunities to clarify fundamental tensions in modern societies. This doctoral dissertation research investigated whether and how visual media reflect and/or drive change in rapidly changing social landscapes. The work provides a unique lens for investigating these dynamic feedbacks in ways that illustrate whether, how, and at what pace expressions of identity change in relation to larger socio-political structures.

Specifically, this project, based in Havana, Cuba, investigated what the economic and aesthetic strategies of contemporary visual media reveal about the socio-economic role of creative work in a society undergoing fundamental political and economic transformations. A principal finding of this project is that the figure of the artist has been both a barometer of and participant in revolutionary Cuba's changing understandings of individuals' socio-political identities. This project arrived at its findings using a combination of ethnographic, archival, and interpretive methods. It integrates participant-observation, the analysis of printed and visual materials, as well as over fifty interviews with stakeholders in Cuba and in the diaspora. This research's aim is to consider how changing understandings of the artist correspond to and/or diverge from changing expectations for individuals over the course of Cuba's socialist history, with particular attention given to the present-day.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in its contribution to anthropological knowledge in three principal areas: identity, (post)socialism, and global artworlds.

Identity: Visual artists form a small sector of society that has depended, since at least the early 1990s, on individual resourcefulness and personal transnational networks for economic survival, a reality which has only been exacerbated during the current economic crisis. An important finding of this project is that today's Cuban artists show a hyper-individualism more typically associated with capitalist contexts. This hyper-individualism is in spite of a long history of socialist thought and pedagogy that posited visual artists as important intellectual workers for imagining a more collectively oriented society. This finding expands anthropological knowledge of individualism as experienced outside of Western, capitalist contexts.

(Post)socialism: This project analyzes a generalized sense of disappointment in a society which has long lost hope in a socialist future (to which the state is still nominally committed). And increasingly, as Cubans look to the predicaments of many formerly socialist and/or recently democratized postcolonial societies, the future of liberal democracy doesn't seem so bright either. Cuban artists' diverse roles over socialist Cuba's 64-year history are particularly illuminating- they have been the darlings of an imagined socialist future; the initial beneficiaries of Cuba's limited forays into a global market-system; among the loudest anti-government activists, and, more recently, some of the more caustic voices of apolitical cynicism. This analysis contributes to the extensive anthropological record on (post)socialist societies undergoing social, political, and economic transformation, while also opening a space for questioning whether (post)socialism continues to be a useful concept.

Global artworlds: This project participates in efforts to shift anthropological inquiry into art away from "traditional" aesthetic practices towards the contemporary, globalized artworld. Many scholars assert that today's artworld cannot be properly understood without paying attention to the massive impact of conceptualism. This research traces conceptualism's trajectory in Cuba, focusing on pedagogical methods and shifting state cultural policy. This historical research is complemented by ethnographic attention to conceptualism's enduring influence in higher arts education, widely shared art ideals, and institutional infrastructures in today's Cuba. Showing how conceptualism's legacy is experienced by artists confronting the tensions and contradictions inherent to a changing society enriches our understanding of the role elite cultural expressions play in broader social processes.

This project is posed to make a broader impact in two areas: 1.) public cultural programming in the US and 2.) US-Cuba cultural and academic exchange. This research allowed for the co-Principal Investigator (co-PI) to develop relationships with independent curators and culture sector public servants with extensive experience exhibiting Cuban artworks outside the island. The co-PI is currently working on two proposals for ethno-historical exhibitions which would broaden the US public's understanding of Cuban cultural life. The independence afforded by NSF funding facilitated connections with a variety of private cultural initiatives, as well as state-run cultural institutions. The ties established as part of this research will be mobilized for the benefit of expanded academic and cultural exchange between the United States and Cuba.
